docs.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Rosen (July 24) misses the point when he says the Supreme Court confirmation battle is ''largely symbolic.'' If Roe is overturned -- or eviscerated -- by the new court, we will return to the days of local control of women's health. That's fine if you're a wealthy woman in an antichoice state, who can fly to New York or Los Angeles or Chicago for an abortion. If you're not, you face the nonchoice of a dangerous, illegal procedure or a forced pregnancy. Simply put, abortion would be criminalized, except for the privileged, educated and mobile. Joan Malin C.E.O., Planned Parenthood of New York City New York

docs.lead_paragraph: According to the Bureau of Justice Statistics, the rate of family violence in this country has dropped by more than half since 1993. I've been trying to figure out why. A lot of the credit has to go to the people who have been quietly working in this field: to social workers who provide victims with counseling and support; to women's crisis centers, which help women trapped in violent relationships find other places to live; to police forces and prosecutors, who are arresting more spouse-beaters and putting them away.
docs.snippet: You want to know what a society looks like when it is in the middle of moral self-repair? Look around.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE navy blue contraption taking up a hefty chunk of floor space inside Kelli M. Conlin's airily modern office at Naral Pro-Choice New York, a leading reproductive-rights group, is more than a piece of functional sculpture. It's the double-seat stroller she uses to wheel her 2-year-old twins around town. Their primary carriage, ''the workhorse Maclaren,'' resides in Brooklyn with Ms. Conlin, who has been Naral's executive director since 1992; her partner of 10 years (she is a lawyer for the city of New York currently on parental leave); and the rambunctious twins (a boy and a girl) conceived the in-vitro way at the fertility center at New York University. Ms. Conlin got lucky on her first try, rare for a woman past 40.

headline.main: Choosing When to Be a Mother Hen

docs.snippet: The executive director of Naral Pro-Choice New York, who denounced the veto of a bill to make the morning-after pill available without a prescription, is a dedicated mother hen.

docs.lead_paragraph: Picture a football player at a party dressed like a hoodlum. That is Jets running back Derrick Blaylock in a snapshot -- but you have to know the context.

headline.main: Blaylock Is a Backup Always Ready to Move Up

docs.snippet: Derrick Blaylock is a throwback, conjuring a time when the bad guys wore black and professional athletes were the good guys.

docs.lead_paragraph: As promised earlier this week, Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed a bill on Thursday that would have made the so-called morning-after pill available to women and girls without a prescription. The veto came just hours after the State Assembly delivered the bill to his desk. Proponents of the emergency contraception bill, including abortion-rights advocates, most Democrats and some leading Republican colleagues of the governor, had urged him to sign the bill, saying it would help prevent more than 80,000 abortions in New York each year. Opponents of the bill, particularly conservatives, pointed out that its main flaw was that minors would have access to the drug, which prevents pregnancy after sex.

headline.main: Pataki Vetoes Bill That Would Ease the Availability of the Morning-After Pill

docs.snippet: As promised earlier this week, Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed a bill that would have made the so-called morning-after pill available to women and girls without a prescription.

docs.lead_paragraph: SINCE the 2004 election, there has been much soul-searching and hand-wringing, especially among Democrats, about how to ''frame'' political messages. The loss to George W. Bush was painful enough, but the Republicans' post-election claims of mandate, and their triumphal promises to relegate the Democrats to permanent minority status, left political liberals in a state of panic. So the minority party has been searching, some would say desperately, for the right ''narrative'': the best story line, metaphors, even magic words to bring back electoral success. The operative term among Democratic politicians and strategists has become ''framing.'' How to tell the story has become more important than the story itself. And that could be a bigger mistake for the Democrats than the ones they made during the election.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Jim Wallis says Democrats are busy looking for right 'narrative' to bring back electoral success, but what they must offer are new ideas and fresh agenda, rather than linguistic strategies; says while language is important in politics, message remains more important than messaging; offers five areas in which Democrats should change their message and then their messaging; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Until Democrats are willing to be honest about the need for compelling political vision, they will never get the message right.

docs.lead_paragraph: The French health authorities have found the remains of 351 stillborn infants and fetuses that were stored illegally in the morgue of a prominent children's hospital, some for more than two decades, according to health officials. The mayor of Paris, Bertrand Delanoë, described the discovery as being ''as surreal as it is illegal.''

headline.main: Discovery of Stored Fetuses And Stillborns Roils France

docs.snippet: French health authorities have found the remains of 351 stillborn infants and fetuses that were stored illegally in the morgue of a prominent children's hospital.

docs.lead_paragraph: PRO BASKETBALL Trail Blazers Waive Van Exel and Anderson The Portland Trail Blazers waived the veteran guards Nick Van Exel and Derek Anderson yesterday. The Blazers chose not to retain Van Exel for the last nonguaranteed year of his contract. Van Exel averaged 10.7 points and 4.3 assists and made 39 starts last season before going on the injured list March 12 with left knee pain. He was acquired in an off-season trade in 2004 that sent forward Dale Davis and guard Dan Dickau to Golden State. Van Exel also played for the Los Angeles Lakers, the Denver Nuggets and the Dallas Mavericks, averaging 15 points and 6.9 assists in his 12-year career.

docs.lead_paragraph: South Korean researchers are reporting today that they have cloned what scientists deem the most difficult animal, the dog. The group worked for nearly three years, seven days a week, 365 days a year and used 1,095 eggs from 122 dogs before finally succeeding with the birth of a cloned male Afghan hound. The surrogate mother was a yellow Labrador retriever.

headline.main: BEATING HURDLES, SCIENTISTS CLONE A DOG FOR A FIRST

docs.abstract: Researchers at Seoul National University report success in cloning dog, considered most difficult animal because of its highly unusual reproductive biology; say group worked for nearly three years and used 1,095 eggs from 122 dogs before succeeding with birth of cloned male Afghan hound on Apr 24; surrogate mother was yellow Labrador retriever; cloning researchers are awed at achievement, which is detailed in journal Nature; others, including bioethicist Nigel Cameron, note that many people see dogs as members of family and see dog cloning as 'dry run' for human cloning debate; cloning researcher Mark E Westhusin, who cloned cat in 2002, says he tried for years to clone dog and then quit; calls dog's reproductive biology, which is even more unusual than human's, a 'nightmare'; timeline with facts on previous animal clonings of sheep, calves, pigs and cat (M)
docs.snippet: South Korean researchers are reporting that they have cloned what scientists deem the most difficult animal, the dog.

multimedia.credit: South Korean scientists announced today that they had created the world's first cloned dog, the 67-day old Snuppy.
multimedia.caption: World's First Cloned Dog

legacy.MultimediaSummary2: South Korean scientists announced today that they had created the world's first cloned dog, the 67-day old Snuppy.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he was disappointed by Gov. George E. Pataki's decision to veto a bill that would make the so-called morning-after pill available without a prescription. ''I would like to see this piece of legislation get enacted,'' the mayor said.

headline.main: Mayor Opposes Pataki Veto on Morning-After Pill

docs.snippet: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday that he was disappointed by Gov. George E. Pataki's decision to veto a bill that would make the so-called morning-after pill available without a prescription.
